data.value: No, no data have been collected for this study yet.

name.value: Study C2: credibility of claim, psychological harm, and punishment.

other.value:
As a manipulation check, participants will complete four questions about each woman’s gender-prototypicality: (1) this woman has a lot in common with other women; (2) this woman is similar to other women; (3) this woman is feminine; and (4) this woman is masculine (reverse). These four items will be averaged to form one gender-prototypicality score, with higher scores indicating that participants thought that Jessica is more prototypical and more feminine. We will use an independent samples t-test to examine whether the gender-prototypicality ratings of Jessica differ by prototypical and non-prototypical conditions. 
Although our previous studies did not find participant gender differences, we will examine if participants’ gender is a moderator for our outcomes given that men and women often perceive ambiguous sexual harassment differently.  For exploratory purposes, we will also ask participants to ‘please describe the sexual harassment you think Jessica experienced’ to examine people’s perceptions of the specifics of the harassing behavior.

sample.value: We aim to run 730 participants with the goal of achieving a sample size of at least 700 after exclusions (with n = 700 we can detect d = .21 with 80% power, alpha = .05, independent samples t-test, 2-tailed test) (G*Power software; Faul, Erdfelder, Buchner, & Lang, 2009).

analyses.value: We will use independent samples t-tests to examine whether the credibility, psychological harm, punishment recommendation ratings of Jessica differ by prototypical and non-prototypical conditions.

outliers.value: We will exclude participants who fail the attention checks and/or respond that they answered randomly.

dependent.value:
Credibility. Participants will be told that Jessica has made a sexual harassment claim against a coworker. They will then rate how much they believe and how confident they are that Jessica was harassed by her coworker on a 7-point scale, with higher numbers indicating higher belief/confidence. These items will be averaged to create a composite ‘credibility’ score.
 
Psychological Harm. Participants will be asked to evaluate how psychologically harmed (upset, distressed, traumatized) Jessica would be if she was harassed by her coworker on a 1 to 7 scale, with higher numbers indicating stronger emotional reactions. These three items will be averaged to create a composite ‘psychological harm’ score.

Punishment Recommendation. Participants will be told that company policy has a 9-tiered system of punishment severity that is used to determine appropriate punishment when sexual harassment occurs within the company.  They will then be asked ‘if an investigation concludes that Jessica was sexually harassed by her coworker, how should the coworker be punished?’ on a 1 (Level 1: informal warning) to 9 (Level 9: termination) scale.

conditions.value: There are two conditions (prototypical vs. non-prototypical). This is a between-subjects design. Each participant will be randomly assigned via Qualtrics to evaluate the prototypical or non-prototypical woman.

hypothesis.value: In Study C2, we will test whether a written manipulation (as opposed to a visual manipulation in Study C1) of a woman’s prototypicality will similarly influence participants’ perceptions of: (a) the credibility of her sexual harassment claim; (b) how psychologically harmed she would be by sexual harassment; and (c) the appropriate punishment for the sexual harasser. Mturk participants will be asked to evaluate a woman named Jessica who is described with either prototypical (e.g., art teacher with stereotypically feminine personality traits and interests) or non-prototypical female characteristics (e.g., physical education teacher with stereotypically masculine personality traits and interests). We predict that participants will: (a) think the non-prototypical woman’s sexual harassment claim is less credible compared to the prototypical woman; (b) give lower psychological harm ratings of sexual harassment for the non-prototypical (vs. prototypical) woman; and (c) give more lenient sexual harassment punishment recommendations for the non-prototypical (vs. prototypical) woman.

data.value: No, no data have been collected for this study yet.

sample.value: We will recruit a total of 225 participants on Amazon's Mechanical Turk.

analyses.value:
We will compute linear mixed effects models with the knew it all along judgments as the outcome variable. Condition (cheating vs. no cheating) will be the fixed effects term; subject and item will be crossed random effects (random intercepts only). This will only be done for the very hard items. The easy items are just filler.

Then, for the cheating condition only, we will identify items that participants in the cheating condition actually cheated on (got the correct answer) in the initial testing phase, and items that participants in the cheating condition did not get the correct answer to. This will be a binary fixed effects term. The outcome variable will be knew it all along judgments. Item and subject will be crossed random effects (random intercepts only). Again, this is only for the very hard trivia items.

If any assumptions are violated, we will collapse across items and run non-parametric statistical tests.

outliers.value:
We have two attention checks. Participants who fail either one will be excluded. The first attention check is to ensure that participants carefully read the instructions about cheating. Here is the attention check question:

True or False: When answering the trivia questions on the following pages, it is cheating to look at the correct answers on the screen or to use outside resources.

Participants who respond False to this question will be excluded from our analyses. Note that this only applies to participants in the cheating condition. This is meant to ensure that we only include in our analyses participants who understand that looking at the answers to the trivia questions is cheating.

The other attention check occurs at the end. Participants will be asked the following: “Do you feel that you paid attention, avoided distractions, and took the survey seriously?” They responded by selecting one of the following: (1) no, I was distracted; (2) no, I had trouble paying attention; (3) no, I didn’t not take the study seriously; (4) no, something else affected my participation negatively; or (5) yes. Participants were ensured that their responses would not affect their payment or their eligibility for future studies. Only those participants who select (5) will be included in the analyses.

dependent.value: The DV is ratings on the "knew it all along" judgments measured on a scale from 1 (this was new to me) to 7 (I actually knew this all along).

conditions.value: Participants will be randomly assigned to one of two conditions. In the cheating condition, participants have the opportunity to cheat on the trivia questions in an initial phase. In the no cheating condition, participants do not have the opportunity to cheat on the trivia questions in an initial phase.

hypothesis.value: When given the opportunity to cheat on a difficult task despite instructions not to cheat (relative to not being given the opportunity to cheat), are participants more likely to say that they just knew the answers all along (prior to beginning the study)?

attributes.title: Wpływ wyobraźni na integrację  multisensoryczną par zmysłów słuch-wzrok i wzrok-smak.
attributes.description:
Badanie ma na celu zbadanie efektu integracji multisensorycznej par zmysłów słuch-wzrok i wzrok-smak oraz zweryfikowanie, czy wyobrażenie sobie bodźca wpływa na integrację multisensoryczną w taki sam sposób, jak jego rzeczywisty odbiór. Badanie składa się z dwóch realizowanych na przemian eksperymentów. 
Pierwszy bada integrację pary zmysłów słuch-wzrok, poprzez wyświetlanie badanym iluzji cross-bounce w czterech warunkach eksperymentalnych: (1) Próba bez dźwięku (2) Próba z rzeczywistym dźwiękiem zderzenia (3) Próba bez dźwięku (4) Próba z wyobrażonym dźwiękiem zderzenia. Drugi eksperyment bada integrację pary zmysłów wzrok-smak. Badani mają wyobrazić sobie wskazany kolor podczas picia napoju owocowego z zamkniętymi oczami bądź wypić napój z otwartymi oczami w zależności od próby: (1) Brak informacji na temat koloru napoju; wypicie napoju z zamkniętymi oczami (warunek kontrolny) (2) Niezgodność rzeczywistego koloru ze smakiem napoju (uczestnicy mają otwarte oczy) (3) Niezgodność wyobrażonego koloru i smaku napoju (4) Niezgodność wyobrażonego koloru i smaku napoju.

q1.value: Wpływ wyobraźni na integrację multisensoryczną par zmysłów słuch-wzrok i wzrok-smak.

q3.value:
Badanie ma na celu zbadanie efektu integracji multisensorycznej par zmysłów słuch-wzrok i wzrok-smak oraz zweryfikowanie, czy wyobrażenie sobie bodźca wpływa na integrację multisensoryczną w taki sam sposób, jak jego rzeczywisty odbiór. 

Integracja multisensoryczna jest istotną częścią natury naszej percepcji. 
Coraz więcej badań wykazuje, że bodźce przetwarzane w jednej modalności 
zmysłowej mogą modulować percepcję bodźców w innych modalnościach 
zmysłowych. Odkrycie wpływu integracji multisensorycznej na percepcję 
bodźców smakowych okazało się na tyle przełomowe, że badania z tego 
zakresu (Zampini et al., 2004) zostały nagrodzone nagrodą Nobla w dziedzinie 
odżywiania. Światowe wiodące marki żywnościowe, takie jak Unilever, Proctor 
& Gamble czy Nestle, wykorzystują tę wiedzę podczas wytwarzania swoich 
produktów. 

Badanie składa się z dwóch realizowanych na przemian eksperymentów. 
Pierwszy bada integrację pary zmysłów słuch-wzrok, poprzez 
wyświetlanie badanym iluzji cross-bounce w czterech warunkach eksperymentalnych: (1) Próba bez dźwięku (2) Próba z rzeczywistym dźwiękiem zderzenia (3) Próba bez dźwięku (4) Próba z wyobrażonym dźwiękiem zderzenia. Drugi eksperyment bada integrację pary zmysłów wzrok-smak. Badani mają wyobrazić sobie wskazany kolor podczas picia napoju owocowego z zamkniętymi oczami bądź wypić napój z otwartymi oczami w zależności od próby: (1) Brak informacji na temat koloru napoju; wypicie napoju z zamkniętymi oczami (warunek kontrolny) (2) Niezgodność rzeczywistego koloru ze smakiem napoju (uczestnicy mają otwarte oczy) (3) Niezgodność wyobrażonego koloru i smaku napoju (4) Niezgodność wyobrażonego koloru i smaku napoju.

q4.value:
Hipoteza 1: Wyobrażenie sobie dźwięku w momencie spotkania się piłek w iluzji cross-bounce będzie skutkowało interpretacją ruchu piłek jako odbijających się od siebie. 

Hipoteza 2: Wyobrażenie sobie koloru niezgodnego z rzeczywistym kolorem spożywanego napoju, będzie skutkowało niepoprawnym rozpoznaniem smaku napoju.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value:
Eksperyment 1:
Schemat wewnątrzgrupowy z 1 zmienną o dwóch poziomach:
dźwięk - (wyobrażony, słyszany)

Eksperyment 2:
Schemat wewnątrzgrupowy z 1 zmienną o czterech poziomach:
kolor - (wyobrażony zgodny ze smakiem; wyobrażony  niezgodny ze smakiem; niewyobrażony zgodny ze smakiem; niewyobrażony  niezgodny ze smakiem)

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: Badani będą rekrutowani wśród studentów Uniwersytetu Jagiellońskiego poprzez ogłoszenia na Facebooku oraz ogłoszenia przypięte do tablic informacyjnych na terenie Uniwersytetu. Badani muszą wyrazić pisemną zgodę na udział w badaniu, nie posiadać dysfunkcji zmysłów słuchu (jeśli istnieje wada słuchu, musi być skorygowana aparatem słuchowym), wzroku (jeśli istnieje wada wzroku, musi być skorygowana okularami), smaku oraz nie mogą być uczuleni na żaden ze składników spożywczych wykorzystanych w badaniu. W zamian za udział w badaniu każdy, kto dokończy procedurę badawczą dostanie 15zł.

q14.value: Jest to próba dająca miarodajne wyniki, a równocześnie pozwalająca przeprowadzić badanie dosyć niskim kosztem.

question.value:
Zmiennymi niezależnymi (manipulowaną) będą:
1. Kolor napoju o czterech poziomach: wyobrażony zgodny ze smakiem; wyobrażony  niezgodny ze smakiem; niewyobrażony zgodny ze smakiem; niewyobrażony  niezgodny ze smakiem 
2. Dźwięk o dwóch poziomach: słyszany; wyobrażony

Będą mierzone postrzeganie piłek w momencie ich spotkania na środku ekranu (zmienna: piłki) oraz odczuwany smak napoju (zmienna: smak), po każdym spożytym napoju, za pomocą kwestionariuszy.

Kwesionariusz 1:
Zobaczysz czterokrotnie dwie niebieskie piłki poruszające się po przekątnych szarego ekranu. Skup uwagę na momencie, w którym piłki spotykają się na środku. Wstaw znak ​X ​w komórce z odpowiadającym efektem zaobserwowanym w momencie spotkania się piłek na środku szarego ekranu.

Kwestionariusz 2:
W każdej próbie wypijesz napój owocowy. Wybierz smak napoju wypitego w danej próbie, poprzez wstawienie znaku ​X ​w komórce z odpowiadającym smakiem.
W każdej próbie możesz zaznaczyć tylko jeden smak.

Do analizy wyników zostanie użyta ANOVA jednoczynnikowa wewnątrzgrupowa, po wcześniejszym teście normalności rozkładu Kołmogorowa-Smirnowa i wykluczeniu danych odstających bądź niekompletnych (poprzez analizę wykresami skrzynkowymi).

q21.value: Zostanie użyte kryterium istotności statystycznej p(<)0.05, by zdeterminować czy ANOVA sugeruje, że wyniki są statystycznie inne od tych spodziewanych w przypadku prawdziwości hipotezy zerowej.

q22.value: Dane odstające zostaną zidentyfikowane podczas analizy wykresami skrzynkowymi i usunięte z wyników branych pod uwagę.

q23.value: Takie dane nie będą brane pod uwagę w analizie.

q25.value:
Inspiracją jest badanie wskazujące na wpływ wyobraźni na integrację m.in. pary zmysłów słuch-wzrok (Berger & Ehrsson, 2013). Osoby badane poproszono o skupienie wzroku na punkcie fiksacji na środku ekranu, a następnie wyświetlono iluzję cross-bounce​. Polegała ona na tym, że dwie kulki pojawiały się w górnym prawym i górnym lewym rogu ekranu i jednostajnie w tym samym tempie zbliżały się do punktu fiksacji, krzyżowały się i znikały w przeciwległych, 
dolnych rogach ekranu. W oryginalnym badaniu (Sekuler et al., 1997) dodanie 
dźwięku zderzenia miało wpływ na interpretację spotkania się kulek w punkcie 
fiksacji jako odbicia, a nie minięcia się. Badanie Bergera i Ehrssona (2013) 
dowiodło natomiast, że zastąpienie prawdziwego bodźca dźwiękowego 
bodźcem wyobrażonym wpływa na interpretację analogicznie. Celem badania jest
replikacja tego wyniku oraz sprawdzenie, czy efekt analogicznego wpływu 
bodźca wyobrażonego na integrację multisensoryczną zajdzie w przypadku 
innej pary zmysłów (wzrok-smak). W tym celu posłużono się metodą z 
badania, w którym uczestnikom podano napoje o smakach owocowych 
zabarwione na kolory niezgodne z danym smakiem (np. czerwony kolor 
napoju pomarańczowego albo zielony kolor napoju wiśniowego) i poproszono 
o określenie smaku (Zampini et al., 2010). Wyniki pokazały wpływ 
niezgodności koloru i smaku napoju na problem w identyfikacji smaku. Jeden 
z warunków mojego badania jest replikacją oryginalnej procedury. Drugi 
warunek jest jej modyfikacją, polegającą na zastąpieniu rzeczywistego koloru 
napoju kolorem wyobrażonym. Modyfikacja ta ma sprawdzić, czy w 
przypadku pary zmysłów wzrok-smak, zastąpienie bodźca rzeczywistego 
bodźcem wyobrażonym, będzie miało efekt podobny do zaobserwowanego w 
przypadku pary zmysłów słuch-wzrok w eksperymencie Bergera i Ehrssona.

registration_responses.q1: Wpływ wyobraźni na integrację multisensoryczną par zmysłów słuch-wzrok i wzrok-smak.

Pierwszy bada integrację pary zmysłów słuch-wzrok, poprzez

Drugi eksperyment bada integrację pary zmysłów wzrok-smak. Badani mają wyobrazić sobie wskazany kolor podczas picia napoju owocowego z zamkniętymi oczami bądź wypić napój z otwartymi oczami w zależności od próby: (1) Brak informacji na temat koloru napoju; wypicie napoju z zamkniętymi oczami (warunek kontrolny) (2) Niezgodność rzeczywistego koloru ze smakiem napoju (uczestnicy mają otwarte oczy) (3) Niezgodność wyobrażonego koloru i smaku napoju (4) Niezgodność wyobrażonego koloru i smaku napoju.

Hipoteza 2: Wyobrażenie sobie koloru niezgodnego z rzeczywistym kolorem spożywanego napoju, będzie skutkowało niepoprawnym rozpoznaniem smaku napoju.

registration_responses.q25:
Inspiracją jest badanie wskazujące na wpływ wyobraźni na integrację m.in. pary zmysłów słuch-wzrok (Berger & Ehrsson, 2013). Osoby badane poproszono o skupienie wzroku na punkcie fiksacji na środku ekranu, a następnie wyświetlono iluzję cross-bounce​. Polegała ona na tym, że dwie kulki pojawiały się w górnym prawym i górnym lewym rogu ekranu i jednostajnie w tym samym tempie zbliżały się do punktu fiksacji, krzyżowały się i znikały w przeciwległych, 
dolnych rogach ekranu. W oryginalnym badaniu (Sekuler et al., 1997) dodanie 
dźwięku zderzenia miało wpływ na interpretację spotkania się kulek w punkcie 
fiksacji jako odbicia, a nie minięcia się. Badanie Bergera i Ehrssona (2013) 
dowiodło natomiast, że zastąpienie prawdziwego bodźca dźwiękowego 
bodźcem wyobrażonym wpływa na interpretację analogicznie. Celem badania jest
replikacja tego wyniku oraz sprawdzenie, czy efekt analogicznego wpływu 
bodźca wyobrażonego na integrację multisensoryczną zajdzie w przypadku 
innej pary zmysłów (wzrok-smak). W tym celu posłużono się metodą z 
badania, w którym uczestnikom podano napoje o smakach owocowych 
zabarwione na kolory niezgodne z danym smakiem (np. czerwony kolor 
napoju pomarańczowego albo zielony kolor napoju wiśniowego) i poproszono 
o określenie smaku (Zampini et al., 2010). Wyniki pokazały wpływ 
niezgodności koloru i smaku napoju na problem w identyfikacji smaku. Jeden 
z warunków mojego badania jest replikacją oryginalnej procedury. Drugi 
warunek jest jej modyfikacją, polegającą na zastąpieniu rzeczywistego koloru 
napoju kolorem wyobrażonym. Modyfikacja ta ma sprawdzić, czy w 
przypadku pary zmysłów wzrok-smak, zastąpienie bodźca rzeczywistego 
bodźcem wyobrażonym, będzie miało efekt podobny do zaobserwowanego w 
przypadku pary zmysłów słuch-wzrok w eksperymencie Bergera i Ehrssona.
registration_responses.q8.question:
Eksperyment 1:
Schemat wewnątrzgrupowy z 1 zmienną o dwóch poziomach:
dźwięk - (wyobrażony, słyszany)

Eksperyment 2:
Schemat wewnątrzgrupowy z 1 zmienną o czterech poziomach:
kolor - (wyobrażony zgodny ze smakiem; wyobrażony  niezgodny ze smakiem; niewyobrażony zgodny ze smakiem; niewyobrażony  niezgodny ze smakiem)
registration_responses.q12.question: Badani będą rekrutowani wśród studentów Uniwersytetu Jagiellońskiego poprzez ogłoszenia na Facebooku oraz ogłoszenia przypięte do tablic informacyjnych na terenie Uniwersytetu. Badani muszą wyrazić pisemną zgodę na udział w badaniu, nie posiadać dysfunkcji zmysłów słuchu (jeśli istnieje wada słuchu, musi być skorygowana aparatem słuchowym), wzroku (jeśli istnieje wada wzroku, musi być skorygowana okularami), smaku oraz nie mogą być uczuleni na żaden ze składników spożywczych wykorzystanych w badaniu. W zamian za udział w badaniu każdy, kto dokończy procedurę badawczą dostanie 15zł.
registration_responses.q16.question:
Zmiennymi niezależnymi (manipulowaną) będą:
1. Kolor napoju o czterech poziomach: wyobrażony zgodny ze smakiem; wyobrażony  niezgodny ze smakiem; niewyobrażony zgodny ze smakiem; niewyobrażony  niezgodny ze smakiem 
2. Dźwięk o dwóch poziomach: słyszany; wyobrażony
registration_responses.q17.question:
Będą mierzone postrzeganie piłek w momencie ich spotkania na środku ekranu (zmienna: piłki) oraz odczuwany smak napoju (zmienna: smak), po każdym spożytym napoju, za pomocą kwestionariuszy.

Kwesionariusz 1:
Zobaczysz czterokrotnie dwie niebieskie piłki poruszające się po przekątnych szarego ekranu. Skup uwagę na momencie, w którym piłki spotykają się na środku. Wstaw znak ​X ​w komórce z odpowiadającym efektem zaobserwowanym w momencie spotkania się piłek na środku szarego ekranu.

Kwestionariusz 2:
W każdej próbie wypijesz napój owocowy. Wybierz smak napoju wypitego w danej próbie, poprzez wstawienie znaku ​X ​w komórce z odpowiadającym smakiem.
W każdej próbie możesz zaznaczyć tylko jeden smak.
registration_responses.q19.question: Do analizy wyników zostanie użyta ANOVA jednoczynnikowa wewnątrzgrupowa, po wcześniejszym teście normalności rozkładu Kołmogorowa-Smirnowa i wykluczeniu danych odstających bądź niekompletnych (poprzez analizę wykresami skrzynkowymi).

attributes.title: Fake news and conspiracy theorizing vs. intellectual humility

q1.value: predicting fake news and conspiracy theory acceptance using intellectual humility

q3.value: In this study, we follow-up on and replicate a study previously published by Marco Meyer (https://social-epistemology.com/2019/10/03/fake-news-conspiracy-and-intellectual-vice-marco-meyer/). Meyer found that acceptance of both fake news and conspiracy theories was predicted (over and above demographics) by scores on the Alfano et al. (2017) Intellectual Humility Scale (https://journals.plos.org/plosone/article?id=10.1371/journal.pone.0182950). We aim to replicate that finding in this pre-registered study. This registration supercedes the registration of January 7, which contained several errors.

q4.value: Acceptance of both fake news and conspiracy theories will be associated with scores on the Alfano et al. (2017) Intellectual Humility Scale. Participants who score higher on IH will be less accepting, whereas participants who score lower on IH will be more accepting. This effect will hold after controlling for participants' educational attainment, race, ethnicity, age, gender, income, political conservatism, and religiosity.

q5.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: Personnel who analyze the data collected from the study are not aware of the treatment applied to any given group.

question.value:
Participants first fill out an attention check (simple arithmetic problem).
Next, they answer demographic questions related to the variables mentioned above.
Next, they fill out the Alfano et al. (2017) intellectual humility questionnaire, which is a 5-point Likert scale. Items from this questionnaire are presented in random order.
Next, they answer three questions that tap their acceptance of conspiracy theories ("Much of what happens in the world today is decided by a small and secretive group of individuals." "Politics is ultimately a struggle between good and evil." and "We are currently living in End Times as foretold by Biblical prophecy."). Agreement is on a 5-point scale.
Next, they are asked how credible various news headlines are. The headlines are presented as screenshots from the online mastheads of various publications, such as the LA Times and InfoWars. Example headlines include "Trump says new proposal will lower some US drug prices" and "Soros's human caravan slowed in Mexico but still pushing North."
Finally, participants rate their agreement with several specific conspiracy theories, such as, "The US invasion of Iraq was not part of a campaign to fight terrorism, but was driven by Jews in the US and Israel." 

Participants' responses are recorded, then used to test the extent to which IH predicts their endorsement of conspiracy theories and their acceptance of fake news as credible.

q9.value: The only randomization is the question order.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: We will use an mTurk sample of approximately 1000 participants, all of whom must be located in the US and have an approval score > 98. They will be paid $1.50 each. We will exclude from analysis any participants who fail the attention check.

q13.value: We will collect data from 1000 participants.

q14.value: 1000 seems to be an adequate sample size for detecting the influence of a personality variable (IH) on acceptance of conspiracy theories and fake news. In his original study that we are replicating, Meyer found significant results with a sample of 975 participants.

question.value: demographics, acceptance/rejection of conspiracy theories, acceptance/rejection of fake news, intellectual humility

We will take the mean of each of the IH scale, along with each of its four IH subscales (4-5 items apiece),. For the conspiracy-acceptance scale, we will count the number of items to which the participant answers with either a 4 or a 5 (indicating that they think the conspiracy theory is true). For credence in fake news, we take the mean acceptance and normalize.
We will test our hypothesis using multiple regression. We will also use structural equation modeling for exploratory analyses of more complex models of the data.

q20.value:
(a) We normalize all variables where this is suitable to allow for easier interpretation of regression results.         

(b) Age: We collect age brackets, which we recode as follows:
<18: 16
18-29: 24
30-39: 34
40-49: 44
50-59: 54
60-69: 64
70 and up: 74

(c) Gender: We treat “other” like “prefer not to say”: as missing data. This is because we expect there will be too few people in this category to meaningfully analyze – this has been the case in previous study.    

(d) Income: we ask for income brackets, which we recode as follows:
<$20,000: 10,000
$20,000-34,999: 27500
$35,000-49,999: 42500
$50,000-74,999: 62500
$75,000-99,999: 87500
>$100,000: 125000

q21.value: We will use p < .05 as our cutoff for significance. In our exploratory analyses using SEM, we will use RMSEA < .1,  SRMR <.1, CFI .95.

q23.value: Participants cannot complete the survey without answering all questions. Participants can, however, can say on demographics that they prefer not to say. We treat this as missing data on the variable where people take this option, but we keep the observation as a whole.

q24.value: We will explore whether some factors of IH have more of an influence on acceptance of fake news and conspiracy theories than others. For instance, it might be that intellectual modesty explains more variance than intellectual engagement. We do not have specific expectations, so all of these analyses will be treated as exploratory.

summary.value:
Singapore Mood/VVG study

This document is intended as the preregistration for a study of the relationship between violent video game playing (VVG) and mental health in the longitudinal study.  This preregistration was developed prior to any data analyses using mental health outcomes.  

VVG and Mental Health

These analyses related to predictors of mental health at Time 3, using predictors at Time 1 and 2.  Note full scale scores will be used for each variable.  No items will be eliminated from any scale unless they reduce reliability below .7 (such eliminations will be detailed in the final manuscript).  Pairwise deletion used for all regressions. 

An effect size of r = .10 will be used as a threshold for determining hypothesis supportive results given concerns of high false positive rates in effect sizes below that size.   

Where applicable, variables that were used in a recent study of aggression outcomes will be calculated identically to that study.  This will limit between-study flexibility using a single database.  See:

Ferguson, C.J., & Wang, C.K.J.  (2019).  Aggressive video games are not a risk factor for future aggression in youth: A longitudinal study.  Journal of Youth and Adolescence 48(8), 1439-1451.   

Predictors (wave 1 unless otherwise specified):
Age
Gender
VVG Wave 1
Time spent gaming wave 1 (check VIFs, will be removed if highly collinear with VVG)
Mothers’ education
Living at Home (8Ha)
Impulse Control
Wave 1 Outcomes for each Wave 3 Outcome variable (Wave 2 for ADHD, Depression, Anxiety, Social Phobia, as W1 not available).

Outcomes:
Somatic Complaints (8hc)
ADHD (11Ka
Depression (11Kb)
Anxiety (11Kc)
Social Phobia (11kd)

An inverse regression predicting Wave 3VVG will also be run using the following predictors.

Age
Gender
VVG Wave 1
Mothers’ education
Living at Home (8H)
Impulse Control (10J)
ADHD (wave 2)
Depression (wave 2)
Anxiety (wave 2)
Social Phobia (wave 2)

attributes.title: Valence, Well Being and Passage of Time

q1.value: Reminiscing and the Passage of Time: Does Valence Matter?

q3.value: In a previous study (Kosak, Kuhbandner, & Hilbert, 2019), we were able to show that the active retrieval of autobiographical memories led to a slower judgement of time passage for the respective interval. The aim of the present study is to examine the impact of the valence of the retrieved memories during reminiscing on passage of time judgments. To this end, the emotional valence of events retrieved during reminiscing is manipulated.

q4.value: The valence of retrieved memories during reminiscing has an effect on subsequently given passage of time judgements (non-directional).

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

q7.value: Subjects will not be aware of the experimental conditions and the purpose of the study. To avoid them thinking about time perception, the study will be framed as a study investigating the relationship between autobiolgraphical memories and well-being.

question.value:
A between-subjects design with the factor of valence of retrieved autobiographical memories during reminiscing (positive vs. negative) will be used. 
Initially, subjective and affective well-being will be measured (questionnaires: SWLS [Glaesmer, Grande, Braehler, & Roth, 2011] and PANAS [Krohne, Egloff, Kohlmann, & Tausch, 1996]). Subsequently, participants will be randomly assigned to one of two reminiscing groups (positive vs. negative autobiographical events). In each of the reminiscing groups, they will be asked to actively retrieve five life events of the respective affective quality. 

After the reminiscing phase, participants will be asked to judge the velocity of the passage of the last five years and the last one year on separate pages. Next, participants will be asked to describe how they derieved their passage of time judgements (open question). Afterwards, they will be asked to retrieve another five life events of the opposite valence compared to the initially retrieved life events. 
Finally, participants will fill out the Protestant Work Ethics Scale (McHoskey, 1994; with some changes to emphasize time) and the Time Pressure Questionnaire (Friedmann & Janssen, 2010) before providing some demographic information (age, gender, occupation and population of hometown).
(see attached image).

q9.value: Participants will be randomly assigned to one of two reminiscing groups (positive vs. negative);  SoSci-survey’s urn-draw-function will be used for assignment.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: Participants will be recruited via advertisments at our university, the website of 'Psychologie Heute', facebook-groups as well as via private contacts. Participants having had a posttraumatic stress disorder or extremely burdensome experiences throughout the last five years are not allowed to take part in the study.

q14.value: Following a power analysis with G*Power, aiming for a Power of 80% with an expected effect of d=.35 (p < .05).

question.value:
Participants in both groups will be asked to name five autobiographical events from the last five years. The instruction reads as:
"On the subsequent pages, we want to ask you to look back on the last five years and recall five [negative/positive] events from your personal life, that you experienced as important (german: prägend) or meaningful. What is considered to be important or meaningful depends only on your subjective experience (german: Wahrnehmung)."

Participants are asked to enter the respective events using keywords; each event has to be entered on a new page within a single empty box.

Passage of time judgements will be measured by asking participants "When you look back: How did the last 5 years pass by for you?". Answers are given on a 7-point-Likert-Scale ranging from very slow to very fast.

SWLS (Glaesmer, Grande, Braehler, & Roth, 2011), PANAS (Krohne, Egloff, Kohlmann, & Tausch, 1996), the Protestand Work Ethics Scale (McHoske, 1994; with some Items exchanged in order to capture more time relevant information) will be measured by using the regarding questionnaires and scales. 
The Time Pressure-Scale will be used as used in Friedmann & Janssen (2010). 

The PANAS-Instructions are adapted to measure the general affective state of participants by asking them how often one experiences the respective emotions usually.

Additionally, we will try to capture the heuristics that participants use to form their passage of time judgements. Therfore we ask them with an open question about what they were thinking about and/or what came to their mind when they made their judgements. The precise question is: "We would like to know how you came to your judgment of the passage of time. Please try to describe what you were thinking or what thoughts were on your mind when you were judging how fast time has passed by."

The main analysis will be a t-test for independent groups comparing the passage of time judgements for five years for the two groups.

We will also compare the groups regarding a number of control variables in order to exclude possible misinterpretations of the basic analysis. These will be compared by a t-Test for independent groups; the variables include age, gender, SWLS, PANAS, Time Pressure, and the Protestant Workt Ethics Scale. Additionally, using a Chi-Square-Test, we will compare whether groups differ regarding the strategies (dummy coded) they used to judge the passage of time.

If any group differences should be found regarding these variables, we will include the respective variables as covariates in our main analysis by using an ANCOVA with the factor group and the respective variable(s) as covariate(s).

q20.value: The open question regarding the heuristics used to make passage of time judgements will be processed in a manual coding process. Our fundamental assumption is that participants will mostly refer to memories when derieving passage of time judgements. Therefore, this will be dummy-coded as 0 = reference to memories / 1 = other strategy.

q22.value: Participants who do report less than five events in the reminising phase before judging the passage of time will be excluded.

To this end, the emotional valence of events retrieved during reminiscing is manipulated.

Next, participants will be asked to describe how they derieved their passage of time judgements (open question). Afterwards, they will be asked to retrieve another five life events of the opposite valence compared to the initially retrieved life events. 
Finally, participants will fill out the Protestant Work Ethics Scale (McHoskey, 1994; with some changes to emphasize time) and the Time Pressure Questionnaire (Friedmann & Janssen, 2010) before providing some demographic information (age, gender, occupation and population of hometown).
(see attached image).
registration_responses.q12.question: Participants will be recruited via advertisments at our university, the website of 'Psychologie Heute', facebook-groups as well as via private contacts. Participants having had a posttraumatic stress disorder or extremely burdensome experiences throughout the last five years are not allowed to take part in the study.
registration_responses.q16.question:
Participants in both groups will be asked to name five autobiographical events from the last five years. The instruction reads as:
"On the subsequent pages, we want to ask you to look back on the last five years and recall five [negative/positive] events from your personal life, that you experienced as important (german: prägend) or meaningful. What is considered to be important or meaningful depends only on your subjective experience (german: Wahrnehmung)."

Participants are asked to enter the respective events using keywords; each event has to be entered on a new page within a single empty box.
registration_responses.q17.question:
Passage of time judgements will be measured by asking participants "When you look back: How did the last 5 years pass by for you?". Answers are given on a 7-point-Likert-Scale ranging from very slow to very fast.

SWLS (Glaesmer, Grande, Braehler, & Roth, 2011), PANAS (Krohne, Egloff, Kohlmann, & Tausch, 1996), the Protestand Work Ethics Scale (McHoske, 1994; with some Items exchanged in order to capture more time relevant information) will be measured by using the regarding questionnaires and scales. 
The Time Pressure-Scale will be used as used in Friedmann & Janssen (2010). 

The PANAS-Instructions are adapted to measure the general affective state of participants by asking them how often one experiences the respective emotions usually.

Additionally, we will try to capture the heuristics that participants use to form their passage of time judgements. Therfore we ask them with an open question about what they were thinking about and/or what came to their mind when they made their judgements. The precise question is: "We would like to know how you came to your judgment of the passage of time. Please try to describe what you were thinking or what thoughts were on your mind when you were judging how fast time has passed by."
registration_responses.q19.question:
The main analysis will be a t-test for independent groups comparing the passage of time judgements for five years for the two groups.

We will also compare the groups regarding a number of control variables in order to exclude possible misinterpretations of the basic analysis. These will be compared by a t-Test for independent groups; the variables include age, gender, SWLS, PANAS, Time Pressure, and the Protestant Workt Ethics Scale. Additionally, using a Chi-Square-Test, we will compare whether groups differ regarding the strategies (dummy coded) they used to judge the passage of time.

If any group differences should be found regarding these variables, we will include the respective variables as covariates in our main analysis by using an ANCOVA with the factor group and the respective variable(s) as covariate(s).

data.value: No, no data have been collected for this study yet.

name.value: Self-control and decision-conflict in environmental decision making (Study 2, confirmatory)

other.value: We will also measure environmental attitudes (NEP-R) and climate beliefs (3-item scale based on previous research) as additional covariates, alongside with demographic variables to assess the robustness of our data.

sample.value: 200 participants will be recruited on Prolific, the number has been decided based on budgetary constraints.

analyses.value: We will run a panel probit regression to estimate our main hypothesis. The trials create a 25-times repeated measure with accept/forego bonus as the dependent variable in each trial. The independent variables of the model are participants'  trait self-control scores, the price/carbon trade-off (5x5) and the interaction thereof. We will build a decision conflict variable consisting of the quotient of price and carbon.

outliers.value: We will exclude all participants who fail to correctly answer  the control question. Additionally, we will exclude participants who fail to make at least 70% (18/25) of the decisions in the trials (decisions are timed and the trial automatically proceeds after 15 seconds).

dependent.value: The dependent variable consists of 25 decisions made by the participants. In each decision, the participant faces a trade-off between a financial reward (i.e., a bonus-opportunity on Prolific) that comes with actual CO2 emissions and foregoing the reward while avoiding the emission. The trials vary in bonus height and amount of CO2 emissions (5x5, fully crossed).

conditions.value: There are 25 within subjects conditions (crossing Co2 and price levels). There are no between-subjects conditions. The main research question involving self-control is correlational.

hypothesis.value: The main research question is whether self-control (measured as trait using the BSCS-scale by Tangney et al.) is a stronger predictor of sustainable decision making in situations involving high conflict between environmental harm and personal gain. Environmental harm is concepualized by Co2 Emissions, personal gains are conceptualized by bonus payments.

data.value: No, no data have been collected for this study yet.

name.value: Self-control translates environmental attitudes into behavior (Berger, Wyss, Study 2, Prolific Replication, 2020).

other.value: We will additionally explore the effect of decision conflict (emission/bonus possible) on behavior. Particularly, we will investigate if self-control is a stronger predictor of behavior in high-conflict trials. Furthermore, we will measure climate change beliefs by a shortened 3-item version of the scale presented in Heath & Gifford (2006). Plausibly, the effects will only occur for people who generally agree that climate change is real and anthropogenic. Additional exploratory controls are age, gender, political ideology, income, education, religiousness.

sample.value: A total of 200 participants are recruited on Prolific.

analyses.value: We will run a panel probit regression to estimate our main hypothesis. The trials create a 25-times repeated measure with accept/forego bonus as the dependent variable in each trial. The independent variables of the model are participants NEP-R scores, their trait self-control scores, and the interaction thereof.

outliers.value: We will exclude all participants who fail to correctly answer the control question. Additionally, we will exclude participants who fail to make at least 70% (18/25) of the decisions in the trials (decisions are timed and the trial automatically proceeds after 15 seconds).

dependent.value: The dependent variable consists of 25 decisions made by the participants. In each decision, the participant faces a trade-off between a financial reward (i.e., a bonus-opportunity on Mturk) that comes with actual CO2 emissions and foregoing the reward while avoiding the emission. The trials vary in bonus height and amount of CO2 emissions (5x5, fully crossed).

conditions.value: The main research question is correlational (effect of NEP-R moderated by self-control on choices), but the trials are a fully crossed 5x5 design enabling us to estimate the effect of CO2 emissions and bonus height on choices. Varying the level of CO2 emissions and bonus height enables us to create a measure of decision conlict (emissions per cent bonus) that will serve as an independent variable.

hypothesis.value:
The main research question is whether trait self-control (measured by the BSCS, Tangney et al.) moderates the effect of environmental attitudes (measured by NEP-R) on pro-environmental choices. 
The main hypothesis is that high values of self-control increase the effect of NEP-R on sustainable decision-making.

attributes.title: Experimental investigation of director independence and objectivity

data.value: It's complicated. We have already collected some data but explain in Question 8 why readers may consider this a valid pre-registration nevertheless.

name.value: Closeness and directors’ tasks - Prolific sample January 2020

other.value:
For exploratory analyses, multiple psychological process variables (e.g. trust, reciprocity) are measured. Separate analyses will be conducted using the psychological processes as mediators. 
Data with actual Dutch non-executive directors in a field experiment has already been collected. However due to restricted availability, only 32 directors participated so far. More efforts to increase sample size of these directors are currently undertaken but sample size will be less than the required sample size for desired levels of statistical power. Therefore, we collect additional data using the Prolific Academic participant pool. It is the collection of this latter sample that we preregister here. The participant pool will be restricted based on demographic characteristics such as having acquired management experience and the age of participants to naturally resemble a more senior audience that is more similar to the population of actual directors.

sample.value: Power analyses using G-power (0.8 power) of our pilot study and pre-tests yield a required sample size of at least 200 participants, requiring 50 participants per condition. We aim to recruit 250 participants to account for possible exclusions and to secure at least 50 participants per condition.

analyses.value: Effects of relational closeness and task type, and their interaction, will be assessed using logistic regression for the dichotomous dependent variable (i.e. decision objectivity) and two-way analyses of variance for the continuous dependent variable. Using simple slopes (for the logistic regression) and pairwise comparisons (for the two-way analysis of variance), we will test the significance of relational closeness within different levels of task type.

outliers.value:
We include attention as well as comprehension checks and use the passing of these as an additional criterion for exclusion for those participants who invest suspiciously little time for the overall experiment, or have an otherwise suspicious response pattern. 
Additionally, outliers will be detected by examination of residuals and how these affect the data. Outliers will be reported and excluded if they cause changes in the results from significant findings to non-significant findings or vice versa.

dependent.value: We proxy participants' objectivity in decision making through the choice in an investment task. We use two different types of dependent variables: (1) whether they choose the fraudulent company out of 4 options (dichotomous variable) or (2) which company they choose out of 4 options (continuous, ranked variable with higher rankings for better-performing companies).

conditions.value: Four conditions based on a 2 (relational closeness: high versus low) x 2 (task type: monitoring versus advice-giving) between participants design. We manipulate the task that participants are instructed to perform and the perceived closeness to the colleague they are working with. Therefore, participants are placed into conditions with combinations of either high closeness and monitoring, high closeness and advising, low closeness and monitoring or low closeness and advising.

hypothesis.value: We test the effects of relational closeness to work colleagues on objectivity in an investment task, and test how this effect depends on the type of task. We predict that the effect of relational closeness on objectivity is moderated by the type of task (monitoring versus advising). More specifically, we hypothesize that relational closeness decreases objectivity for participants who have a monitoring task and increases objectivity for participants who have an advisory task.

q1.value: Digital media supporting literacy learning in children with communicative and cognitive disabilities

q2.value: Lisa Palmqvist, Jenny Samuelsson, Emil Holmer, Mary Rudner, Mats Lundälv, Monica Reichenberg, Katarina Mühlenbock, Gunilla Thunberg, Mikael Heimann

q3.value:
Children with intellectual and communicative disabilities may be among the most socially disadvantaged student categories. Failing in acquiring literacy skills is a serious and common problem. The purpose of this project is to investigate the effects of two specific digital literacy learning tools (apps) on the acquisition of literacy skills in children with intellectual disability and who are reliant on augmentative and alternative communication, AAC. This means that they need aids such as manual signing, symbols/pictures, speech-generating devices, etc. to understand and/or express themselves. 

We will recruit children with intellectual disability of different etiologies from special needs schools. The age range will be broad. The children will be assigned to one of three interventions or to a comparison group that will receive teaching-as-usual (TaU). The three interventions are: 1) the ALL-Accessible Literacy Learning app (phonemic strategies); the Animega-is app (comprehension-based strategies); 3) a combination of both ALL and Animega-is. The children’s literacy development during a 12-week intervention period will be compared across the four different groups. In line with a previous study targeting children in reading difficulties (Gustafson et al., 2011), we expect a positive effect on reading and phonological awareness across all intervention groups, with the largest effect in the group receiving the combined intervention.

q4.value:
1: Training phonemic or comprehension-based reading strategies improves phonological awareness. 
2: Training phonemic or comprehension-based reading strategies improves reading ability. 
3: The combined training is more effective than either intervention on its own.

 The hypotheses will be tested on these outcome variables: phonological awareness (1, 3), word reading (2, 3), and sentence reading (2, 3).

q5.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: Personnel who analyze the data collected from the study are not aware of the treatment applied to any given group.

q7.value: We do not tell the participants which intervention is believed to be most beneficial.

question.value: We have a mixed design with four groups (TaU, ALL, Animega-is, and ALL+Animega-is), four measurement points (T1-T4), and three outcome variables (phonological awareness, word reading, and sentence reading). T1 takes place before the start of the intervention (week 0), T2 six weeks into the intervention (~week 7), T3 at the end of the intervention (week 13), and T4 approximately 6 weeks after the end of the intervention. TaU follows the same procedure as the intervention groups.

q9.value:
The children will be assigned to one of the four groups: TaU, ALL, Animega, or ALL+Animega. 

For practical reasons, data collection for TaU begins six months before data collection for the intervention groups. Recruitment of participants will continue during these six months, and therefore assignment to TaU is not based on randomization from the total sample recruited for the study. From the sample available at the start of data collection, 30 are assigned to TaU and the rest will be on a waiting list. TaU and waiting list groups will be matched on level of intellectual disability, grade, communication, and adaptive skills. As regards the interventions, participants who belong to the same school class will always be assigned to the same intervention as determined by randomization. For ethical and practical reasons, we will not randomize at an individual level.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value:
The aim is to recruit 120 (4 groups x 30 participants) children with intellectual disability who are reliant on augmentative and alternative communication to manage their communication. They will be recruited through existing contact with Swedish special needs schools for children with intellectual disabilities. A further inclusion criterion is that at the start of the intervention, participants cannot read more than 20 written words, as judged by their teachers. No exclusion criteria will be applied. 

Participants will be recruited primarily from special needs schools for children with intellectual disabilities in the southern parts of Sweden. Schools will be informed about the study and will be invited to express their interest in participating. Once schools have expressed an interest in participating in the study, information about the study and consent forms will be distributed to parents of selected children. Written consent from parents is collected at the schools. After the end of the study, the schools will continue to have access to the apps used in the intervention. 

Recruitment will start in November 2019 and will be discontinued when 120 participants have been assigned to one of the groups, or in December 2020. Data collection starts in spring 2020 and ends in summer 2021.

q13.value: Our target sample size is 120 participants.

q14.value:
Power calculations were performed with ANOVApower (Lakens & Caldwell, 2019) simulations (see below). Based on a mixed group (TaU, ALL, Animega-is, Combined) by time (T1, T2, T3, T4) ANOVA, and an expected effect of 0.8 SDs between conditions at T3, 30 participants per condition suffice for at least 80% power (within-subject correlation on outcome measure of .70 and uncorrected alpha level of .05). Effect size estimates are based on Gustafson et al. (2011) and Fälth et al. (2013). 

ANOVA_design(design = "4b*4w",
n = 30,
mu = c(0, 0, 0, 0, 0, 0.4, 0.8, 0.8, 0, 0.4, 0.8, 0.8, 0, 0.8, 1.6, 1.6),
sd = 1,
r = 0.7, 
labelnames = c("group", "TaU", "ALL", "Animega", "Combined", "time", "t1","t2", "t3", "t4"))

ANOVA_power("ANOVA_design",
alpha_level = 0.05,
nsims = 1000,
verbose = TRUE)

Power and Effect sizes for ANOVA tests
                                 power    effect_size
anova_group          98           0.16
anova_time             100         0.34
anova_group:time 100         0.22

Power and Effect sizes for contrasts
                                                                                                     power  effect_size
p_group_TaU_time_t3_group_All_time_t3                             88         0.80
p_group_TaU_time_t3_group_Animega-is_time_t3              87         0.82
p_group_TaU_time_t3_group_Combined_time_t3               100       1.63
p_group_All_time_t3_group_Combined_time_t3                  86         0.81
p_group_Animega-is_time_t3_group_Combined_time_t3   86         0.80

q15.value: Even though we aim at 30 participants in each group, data collection will stop in summer 2021 due to time constraints in the project.

question.value: We will manipulate the type of literacy training that participant will receive. The four levels of this variable are: teaching-as-usual (TaU), phonemic reading strategy, comprehension-based reading strategy, or combined phonemic/comprehension-based reading strategy.

(1) Phonological awareness: MiniDUVAN (Wolff, 2013) We will use five subtests from MiniDUVAN (Wolff, 2013) to assess phonological awareness skills: A1 Morpheme identification, A2 Rhyme identification, A3 Phoneme identification, B4 Phoneme synthesis, C1 Morpheme manipulation. The dependent measure is total number of correct answers across all subtests (max = 45). 

(2) Word reading: OS64 (Nielsen et al., 1997) and OLAF (Magnusson & Naucler, 2010) Adapted versions of OS64 (Nielsen et al., 1997) and OLAF (Magnusson & Naucler, 2010) will be used to assess word reading skills. In OS64 the participant match a written word to a widgit symbol, and in OLAF written words are matched to pictures. The dependent measure is total number of correct answers (max = 15 for OS64, and max = 20 for OLAF). 

(3) Sentence reading: DLS Bas (Järpsten, 2004) In DLS Bas (Järpsten, 2004) the participant read short sentences and match these to their corresponding pictures. The dependent measure is total number of correct answers (max = 20).

For word reading, we will transform raw scores for each test (OS64 and OLAF) on a comparable scale (e.g. standardized scores), and average the scaled scores to create a word reading index. No other indices will be created.

Distribution of data will be checked. With normally distributed data, three two-way mixed ANOVA with one between-subject factor, Group (TaU, ALL, Animega-is, Combined), and one within-subject factor, Time (T1-T4), will be performed: one for Phonological awareness, one for Word reading, and one for Sentence reading. We expect a main effect of time and an interaction between Group and Time, driven by different trajectories between groups during the intervention (T1 to T3). At T3, we expect ALL, Animega-is and Combined to perform at a higher level than TaU, which will be tested by planned contrasts: ALL-TaU, Animega-is-TaU, and Combined-TaU. We further expect stronger performance at T3 in the Combined group compared to ALL and to Animega-is, which will be tested by planned contrast: Combined-ALL and Combined-Animega-is. 

If the assumption of normality is violated (indicated by statistical test and/or detection of outlier/s), robust ANOVA using trimmed means and bootstrapping will be applied (see Field & Wilcox, 2017).

q20.value: For word reading, we will transform raw scores for each test (OS64 and OLAF) on a comparable scale (e.g. standardized scores), and average the scaled scores to create a word reading index.

q21.value: We will use p-values as our inference criteria. To minimize the risk of Type 2 errors, an uncorrected alpha level of .05 is applied. We will only test the specified hypotheses, applying five two-tailed follow-up tests for the interaction Time by Group in each ANOVA.

q22.value: No checks will be performed to determine eligibility for inclusion. Outliers will be included in the analysis (see "Statistical models").

q23.value: Missing data will be dealt with by imputation using maximum likelihood estimation.

q24.value: No difference in outcome is predicted between the All and Animega-is conditions. However, these conditions will be compared at T3, in an exploratory analysis.

q25.value:
Relevant literature

Clendon, S. (2011). Literacy interventions for students who use aided augmentative and alternative communication: More work to be done. Evidence-Based Communication Assessment and Intervention, 5(3), 138-143.

Field, A. P., & Wilcox, R. R. (2017). Robust statistical methods: A primer for clinical psychology and experimental psychopathology researchers. Behaviour Research and Therapy, 98, 19-38.

Lakens, D., & Caldwell, A. R. (2019, May 28). Simulation-Based Power-Analysis for Factorial ANOVA Designs. https://doi.org/10.31234/osf.io/baxsf

Light, J., & McNaughton, D. (2012). Supporting the communication, language, and literacy development of children with complex communication needs: State of the science and future research priorities. Assistive Technology, 24, 34-44.

registration_responses.q1: Digital media supporting literacy learning in children with communicative and cognitive disabilities
registration_responses.q2: Lisa Palmqvist, Jenny Samuelsson, Emil Holmer, Mary Rudner, Mats Lundälv, Monica Reichenberg, Katarina Mühlenbock, Gunilla Thunberg, Mikael Heimann
registration_responses.q3:
Children with intellectual and communicative disabilities may be among the most socially disadvantaged student categories. Failing in acquiring literacy skills is a serious and common problem. The purpose of this project is to investigate the effects of two specific digital literacy learning tools (apps) on the acquisition of literacy skills in children with intellectual disability and who are reliant on augmentative and alternative communication, AAC. This means that they need aids such as manual signing, symbols/pictures, speech-generating devices, etc. to understand and/or express themselves. 

We will recruit children with intellectual disability of different etiologies from special needs schools. The age range will be broad. The children will be assigned to one of three interventions or to a comparison group that will receive teaching-as-usual (TaU). The three interventions are: 1) the ALL-Accessible Literacy Learning app (phonemic strategies); the Animega-is app (comprehension-based strategies); 3) a combination of both ALL and Animega-is. The children’s literacy development during a 12-week intervention period will be compared across the four different groups. In line with a previous study targeting children in reading difficulties (Gustafson et al., 2011), we expect a positive effect on reading and phonological awareness across all intervention groups, with the largest effect in the group receiving the combined intervention.
registration_responses.q4:
1: Training phonemic or comprehension-based reading strategies improves phonological awareness. 
2: Training phonemic or comprehension-based reading strategies improves reading ability. 
3: The combined training is more effective than either intervention on its own.

 The hypotheses will be tested on these outcome variables: phonological awareness (1, 3), word reading (2, 3), and sentence reading (2, 3).
registration_responses.q5: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.
q6: Personnel who analyze the data collected from the study are not aware of the treatment applied to any given group.
registration_responses.q7: We do not tell the participants which intervention is believed to be most beneficial.
registration_responses.q9:
The children will be assigned to one of the four groups: TaU, ALL, Animega, or ALL+Animega. 

For practical reasons, data collection for TaU begins six months before data collection for the intervention groups. Recruitment of participants will continue during these six months, and therefore assignment to TaU is not based on randomization from the total sample recruited for the study. From the sample available at the start of data collection, 30 are assigned to TaU and the rest will be on a waiting list. TaU and waiting list groups will be matched on level of intellectual disability, grade, communication, and adaptive skills. As regards the interventions, participants who belong to the same school class will always be assigned to the same intervention as determined by randomization. For ethical and practical reasons, we will not randomize at an individual level.

registration_responses.q13: Our target sample size is 120 participants.
registration_responses.q14:
Power calculations were performed with ANOVApower (Lakens & Caldwell, 2019) simulations (see below). Based on a mixed group (TaU, ALL, Animega-is, Combined) by time (T1, T2, T3, T4) ANOVA, and an expected effect of 0.8 SDs between conditions at T3, 30 participants per condition suffice for at least 80% power (within-subject correlation on outcome measure of .70 and uncorrected alpha level of .05). Effect size estimates are based on Gustafson et al. (2011) and Fälth et al. (2013). 

ANOVA_design(design = "4b*4w",
n = 30,
mu = c(0, 0, 0, 0, 0, 0.4, 0.8, 0.8, 0, 0.4, 0.8, 0.8, 0, 0.8, 1.6, 1.6),
sd = 1,
r = 0.7, 
labelnames = c("group", "TaU", "ALL", "Animega", "Combined", "time", "t1","t2", "t3", "t4"))

ANOVA_power("ANOVA_design",
alpha_level = 0.05,
nsims = 1000,
verbose = TRUE)

registration_responses.q15: Even though we aim at 30 participants in each group, data collection will stop in summer 2021 due to time constraints in the project.
registration_responses.q20: For word reading, we will transform raw scores for each test (OS64 and OLAF) on a comparable scale (e.g. standardized scores), and average the scaled scores to create a word reading index.
registration_responses.q21: We will use p-values as our inference criteria. To minimize the risk of Type 2 errors, an uncorrected alpha level of .05 is applied. We will only test the specified hypotheses, applying five two-tailed follow-up tests for the interaction Time by Group in each ANOVA.
registration_responses.q22: No checks will be performed to determine eligibility for inclusion. Outliers will be included in the analysis (see "Statistical models").
registration_responses.q23: Missing data will be dealt with by imputation using maximum likelihood estimation.
registration_responses.q24: No difference in outcome is predicted between the All and Animega-is conditions. However, these conditions will be compared at T3, in an exploratory analysis.

registration_responses.q8.question: We have a mixed design with four groups (TaU, ALL, Animega-is, and ALL+Animega-is), four measurement points (T1-T4), and three outcome variables (phonological awareness, word reading, and sentence reading). T1 takes place before the start of the intervention (week 0), T2 six weeks into the intervention (~week 7), T3 at the end of the intervention (week 13), and T4 approximately 6 weeks after the end of the intervention. TaU follows the same procedure as the intervention groups.
registration_responses.q12.question:
The aim is to recruit 120 (4 groups x 30 participants) children with intellectual disability who are reliant on augmentative and alternative communication to manage their communication. They will be recruited through existing contact with Swedish special needs schools for children with intellectual disabilities. A further inclusion criterion is that at the start of the intervention, participants cannot read more than 20 written words, as judged by their teachers. No exclusion criteria will be applied. 

Participants will be recruited primarily from special needs schools for children with intellectual disabilities in the southern parts of Sweden. Schools will be informed about the study and will be invited to express their interest in participating. Once schools have expressed an interest in participating in the study, information about the study and consent forms will be distributed to parents of selected children. Written consent from parents is collected at the schools. After the end of the study, the schools will continue to have access to the apps used in the intervention. 

Recruitment will start in November 2019 and will be discontinued when 120 participants have been assigned to one of the groups, or in December 2020. Data collection starts in spring 2020 and ends in summer 2021.
registration_responses.q16.question: We will manipulate the type of literacy training that participant will receive. The four levels of this variable are: teaching-as-usual (TaU), phonemic reading strategy, comprehension-based reading strategy, or combined phonemic/comprehension-based reading strategy.
registration_responses.q17.question:
(1) Phonological awareness: MiniDUVAN (Wolff, 2013) We will use five subtests from MiniDUVAN (Wolff, 2013) to assess phonological awareness skills: A1 Morpheme identification, A2 Rhyme identification, A3 Phoneme identification, B4 Phoneme synthesis, C1 Morpheme manipulation. The dependent measure is total number of correct answers across all subtests (max = 45). 

(2) Word reading: OS64 (Nielsen et al., 1997) and OLAF (Magnusson & Naucler, 2010) Adapted versions of OS64 (Nielsen et al., 1997) and OLAF (Magnusson & Naucler, 2010) will be used to assess word reading skills. In OS64 the participant match a written word to a widgit symbol, and in OLAF written words are matched to pictures. The dependent measure is total number of correct answers (max = 15 for OS64, and max = 20 for OLAF). 

(3) Sentence reading: DLS Bas (Järpsten, 2004) In DLS Bas (Järpsten, 2004) the participant read short sentences and match these to their corresponding pictures. The dependent measure is total number of correct answers (max = 20).
registration_responses.q18.question: For word reading, we will transform raw scores for each test (OS64 and OLAF) on a comparable scale (e.g. standardized scores), and average the scaled scores to create a word reading index. No other indices will be created.
registration_responses.q19.question:
Distribution of data will be checked. With normally distributed data, three two-way mixed ANOVA with one between-subject factor, Group (TaU, ALL, Animega-is, Combined), and one within-subject factor, Time (T1-T4), will be performed: one for Phonological awareness, one for Word reading, and one for Sentence reading. We expect a main effect of time and an interaction between Group and Time, driven by different trajectories between groups during the intervention (T1 to T3). At T3, we expect ALL, Animega-is and Combined to perform at a higher level than TaU, which will be tested by planned contrasts: ALL-TaU, Animega-is-TaU, and Combined-TaU. We further expect stronger performance at T3 in the Combined group compared to ALL and to Animega-is, which will be tested by planned contrast: Combined-ALL and Combined-Animega-is. 

If the assumption of normality is violated (indicated by statistical test and/or detection of outlier/s), robust ANOVA using trimmed means and bootstrapping will be applied (see Field & Wilcox, 2017).
